entry.title: A Failed Attempt at Implementing an Organization-Level HRBP Enhancement via Integration Center
entry.content:
Today, I’d like to share a solution attempt for enhancing organization-level HRBP management in SuccessFactors via Integration Center — and why it ultimately fell short. This idea originated from a customer requirement to manage HRBPs at the department level (similar to how department heads are managed), rather than at the individual or position level.

1. Requirement

Many customers prefer to manage HRBPs by department instead of person or position.
In this model:

  • HRBPs are maintained only in department data, not in job relationships.
  • Any HRBP update (due to termination, transfer, etc.) should automatically affect all employees under that department.

2. Typical Use Case

Example: In the Finance Department, HRBPs differ by region:

  • Finance – USA → HRBP A
  • Finance – Germany → HRBP B
  • Finance – China → HRBP C

An employee’s HRBP should be determined based on their department and location.

3. Background

Currently, standard SuccessFactors does not support HRBP management at the organization level.
Key points:

  • HRBP data can only be maintained in position relationships and job relationships, with synchronization between these two tables.
  • Maintaining HRBPs at the organization (department) level is unsupported, and cannot be automatically synced to employees’ job relationship data.

4. Custom Integration Enhancement Solution

Process Overview

The enhancement was designed with the following steps:

Step 1 – Create a Custom MDF Object
Create a departmentHR MDF object as a child of the Department general object.

Field Type Note
externalCodeStringAuto-generated — concatenates relationshipType and HRBP user ID
cust_HRUserHRBP User ID
cust_LocationGeneric ObjectLocation

Step 2 – Output Integration Center Job
Export employee job data (empJob) including:

  • userId
  • effectiveDate
  • sequence
  • location
  • Calculated column: HRBP (derived from location + division in job info)

 

Step 3 – Input Integration Center Job
Import and update job relationship records for each job info record, based on the exported data.

5. Limitation

This approach fails in scenarios where HRBP changes are future-dated but employees have no corresponding future-dated job info record.

Example:

Job Info:

UserId EffectiveDate HRBP
Employee-A2023-01-01A
Employee-A2024-01-02B

Department Data:

Department EffectiveDate HRBP
Dept-A2020-01-01A
Dept-A2024-01-01B
Dept-A2025-01-01C

Result: C will not appear for Employee-A until they have a job info record effective after 2025-01-01. This happens because:

  • empJob’s effective date is not derived from department effective dates.
  • Department data is fetched as of the job info’s effective date.
  • The future effective department record cannot be retrieved from empJob.

6. Thoughts for Improvement

  1. API-based Enhancement

    • Use API queries to:
      • Retrieve all employees under the department.
      • Retrieve all effective department records.
    • Insert corresponding HRBP records into job info for any date range between department effective dates.

  2. Using Standard “Manage Mass Change”

    • In standard SF, HRIS can use the Manage Mass Change tool to update HRBPs quickly whenever they change — even though this is manual, not automated.

7. Closing Thoughts

While this solution didn’t achieve the desired automation, I hope it provides some insight and sparks discussion. I’d greatly appreciate any thoughts on:

  • Why organization-level HRBP management is not considered best practice in SuccessFactors
  • Whether there are better workarounds for this requirement

entry.title: Automatically Start Sybase Database and SAP Application on the Same Host
entry.content:
Overview

In many SAP landscapes, the Sybase database and SAP application run on the same host. By creating automation scripts and integrating them with systemd services, we can ensure both the Sybase database and SAP application start automatically whenever the VM is powered on from the GCP Console — without any manual intervention.

Architecture

Since the database and application are hosted on the same server, the sequence is straightforward:

  • Start the Sybase database (dataserver and backup server)
  • Wait for the database to be fully online
  • Start the SAP application

1. Sybase + SAP Application Auto Start Script

File: /usr/local/bin/start_sybase_sap.sh
Purpose: Start Sybase dataserver, Sybase backup server, and SAP application in sequence.

#!/bin/csh

# Set environment
unsetenv LANG
setenv LANG us_english.utf8

cd /sybase/<SYBASE_DIR>
source SYBASE.csh

# Log file
set LOGFILE="/usr/sap/start_sybase_sap.log"

echo "===== Starting Sybase and SAP at `date` =====" >>& $LOGFILE

# Start dataserver
echo "Starting Sybase dataserver..." >>& $LOGFILE
$SYBASE/$SYBASE_ASE/install/RUN_<DB_NAME> >>& $LOGFILE &

sleep 120  # Wait 2 minutes for dataserver to initialize

# Check if dataserver is running
ps -ef | grep "dataserver" | grep "\-s<DB_NAME>" | grep -v grep > /dev/null
if ($status != 0) then
    echo "Error: dataserver did not start successfully." >>& $LOGFILE
    exit 1
endif

# Start backup server
echo "Starting Sybase backup server..." >>& $LOGFILE
$SYBASE/$SYBASE_ASE/install/RUN_<BACKUP_NAME> >>& $LOGFILE &

sleep 30

# Start SAP application
echo "Switching to SAP admin user to start SAP..." >>& $LOGFILE
su - <SAP_ADMIN_USER> -c 'startsap R3' >>& $LOGFILE

echo "===== Finished at `date` =====" >>& $LOGFILE
exit 0

4. systemd Service Unit

File: /etc/systemd/system/sybase_sap_start.service
Purpose: Run the startup script automatically at boot.

[Unit]
Description=Start Sybase and SAP Automatically at Boot
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=forking
User=root
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/start_sybase_sap.sh
Restart=no
TimeoutSec=600

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target

5. Enabling the Service

Run the following commands:

chmod +x /usr/local/bin/start_sybase_sap.sh
sudo systemctl daemon-reexec
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable sybase_sap_start.service
sudo systemctl start sybase_sap_start.service
sudo systemctl status sybase_sap_start.service

6. Monitoring and Logs

  • Startup Logs: /usr/sap/start_sybase_sap.log

  • Logs contain timestamped entries for each step — useful for debugging in case of startup issues.

7. Benefits of This Setup

  • Zero manual intervention after VM boot
  • Correct sequence — Sybase DB starts before SAP
  • Detailed logging for troubleshooting

Conclusion

With this configuration, both Sybase database and SAP application automatically start after a VM reboot on GCP. The approach ensures reliability, reduces human error, and speeds up system availability.

Regards,

Nitin Khose

entry.title: Harnessing SAP Analytics Cloud AI Assisted Advanced Formula Generation Capabilities in QRC3.2025
entry.content:
Harnessing SAP Analytics Cloud AI Assisted Advanced Formula Generation Capabilities in QRC3.2025

We are pleased to announce the release of AI assisted advanced formula generation capabilities in our QRC3.2025 release.  SAP Analytics Cloud provides planners the ability to leverage artificial intelligence (AI) to create advanced formulas scripts and script comments within the advanced formulas step of a data actions.  Please browse the SAP Business AI catalog for more business value information and pricing details.

Prerequisites

Check that you have met all the necessary prerequisites, which includes activating the feature, which is detailed here.

 

Key benefits

The goal of this enhancement is to make advanced formulas scripting more accessible to the planner and to accelerate their productivity by:

  1. Simplifying the creation of technical scripts – use business comments to guide AI to generate a technical script
  2. Documenting technical scripts – Select a technical script and have AI generate a comment to explain the calculation in business terms.

Basics of AI-Generated Scripts and Comments

To generate scripts or script-comments using AI, planners will also require to meet the requirements to be able to create/edit advanced formulas.  AI can assist in generating scripts by translating business comments into technical scripts. Similarly, it can generate clear business comments based on existing technical scripts. During script/comment generation, the AI offers suggestions which appear highlighted to indicate they are generated and prompts users to either accept or reject the output. Notably, all generated scripts and script comments include a cautionary note to verify results before use, underscoring the importance of human oversight to manage the overall process.

 

Tips for Effective Usage

When generating advanced formula scripts from a business comment, it's beneficial to be specific as possible using specific members/dimensions names to make it easier for the AI accurately to understand the request. It is advisable, however, not to base script generation solely on the AI-generated comments since these may not capture every technical detail appropriately.  Generated scripts may benefit from a human technical review and testing to validate the logic and make any minor script adjustments as needed that were not captured by the original prompt.

For script comment generation, focusing on a single line of a formula script might yield the most detailed insights. Likewise, if the formula script selection is large, the AI provides more generalized comments to document the script.

Explore With Examples

The platform also provides examples of both script and comment generations, assisting users in understanding how AI interprets various scenarios and implements solutions. These examples range from basic arithmetic optimizations in financial data to looping through dimensions for iterative calculations.

 Generating Comment from Advanced Formulas Script

Generate Advanced Formulas Script from a comment

In Conclusion

Whether you're a seasoned data analyst or new to SAP Analytics Cloud, integrating AI into your workflow will significantly enhance your ability to efficiently generate advanced formula scripts and script comments.

entry.title: SAP Activate community blog post highlights from this summer
entry.content:
In this blog post, I’d like to highlight some of the excellent posts from the SAP Community authored under the SAP Activate managed tag. My goal is to draw your attention to these outstanding contributors and ensure that, even if you were on vacation this summer, you didn’t miss any of the exciting posts. You can find a full list of posts with the SAP Activate tag at this link. We will begin with the posts from June up to today.

Learn Quickly via the SAP Activate Minute Videos

The first post comes from Dan, who shares a great resource for bite-sized learning in the SAP Activate Minute playlist. Have a look at Dan’s blog and explore the SAP Activate learning videos in the playlist.

 

Say Hi to Joule in SAP Activate road map viewer

The next exciting post comes from Chandan, who shared the news about the availability of Joule on the SAP Activate road map viewer, where you can conduct natural conversation with Joule to get SAP Activate guidance or access specific accelerators and resources. We are all very excited that we can now bring this new feature to all our users.

 

NEW SAP Activate provisioning road map for SAP Business Suite packages

In this blog post, Adnette shared an update for our customers who are starting the SAP Business Suite journey with SAP Cloud ERP. The post introduces a new SAP Activate road map designed to ease the first provisioning and setup steps for your Starter environment, including the setup of the SAP BTP global account and sub-account and the provisioning and setup of your SAP Cloud ALM environment.

 

Explore the SAP Activate Methodology using a reimagined Road Map Viewer

Ana shares another set of exciting updates about the visual refresh of the SAP Activate road map viewer environment, including the refreshed onboarding experience for our new users. The new guided process introduces new users not only to the tool and its features but also discusses the structure of the SAP Activate content and helps new users find the information they need.

 

How to Use the XML File from the SAP Activate Project Plan to Create a Microsoft Project File

In her second post this summer, Adnette shares a step-by-step procedure for downloading the project plan accelerator in XML format and importing it into MS Project for use with your project team. The example shows you how to do this for your upcoming implementation (or system conversion, or selective data transition) of SAP Cloud ERP Private.

 

Accelerating Implementation with SAP Activate in the Public Cloud

In this post, the user pranavgarud shares his experience from using SAP Activate during the implementation of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition solution at a customer. He provides not only an overview of what is done in each phase but also shares highlights of the 16-week-long journey to deploy the solution.

 

Navigating SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Greenfield Implementations: Lessons Learned from the Frontlines

And we will close the list with a post from member S_MAHAMMAD_RAFI, who shares thoughts and lessons in 5 areas of the implementation in a greenfield environment. The five areas include discussion about SAP Best Practices, global collaboration across distributed teams, use of agile, risk & quality management, and critical lessons learned.

 

I encourage you all to read through those excellent blog posts and engage in conversation with the authors in the comments to their respective blog posts. I want to express sincere thanks to everyone who found time to share their experience, expertise, and news with the community.

Thank You and enjoy the rest of your summer!

entry.title: Managing Subscriptions in S/4HANA Public Cloud as a software reseller
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

One of our main business activities is reselling subscription-based software from a large software OEM. We are currently exploring SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud with a fit-to-standard approach and are looking for the optimal way to manage and bill our subscriptions.

We have been advised to look into several possible approaches, including:

  • SAP Subscription Billing
  • Service Contracts
  • Recurring WBS items in Projects
  • Sales Orders
  • Solution Orders

SAP Subscription Billing seems to be an obvious candidate, but it appears to be more suited for companies selling their own subscriptions with usage-based rate plans or complex pricing schemes. The setup seems like an overkill for our business processes with a more complicated process to create and manage subscriptions than necessary for us. The standard setup without using Solution Orders also allows you to only create 1 subscription at a time while we want to manage and create subscription contracts that contain multiple different products. 

In our use case we just have a order from a client with multiple products, each with its own quantity, subscription term and annual price that we would need to enter into SAP, prepare the billing on an annual/quarterly/monthly basis and make sure the revenue is recognized across the subscription term per day. 

We need a simple, user-friendly solution that allows us to:

  • Manage multiple subscriptions under a single customer contract
  • Define subscription terms and pricing per license line
  • Automate annual billing and revenue recognition
  • Match the revenue of the subscription with the purchase cost for margin calculation
  • Provide accurate KPI insights such as MRR and churn

Is there anyone in this community with a similar business model as subscription software reseller on SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud? I would be very interested to hear your experiences and which solution you chose for managing and billing subscriptions.

Thanks,
Vasco

SAP Subscription Billing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

entry.title: Seamless Transition from SAP Solution Manager 7.2 to SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Seamless Transition from SAP Solution Manager 7.2 to SAP Cloud ALM

A Phased, Step-by-Step Guide

  1. Understand the Transition Landscape

SAP is moving towards cloud-based Application Lifecycle Management, and SAP Cloud ALM (CALM) is the natural successor to SAP Solution Manager (SolMan) for most operational and implementation use cases.
Refer to SAP Note 3255311 for details on SAP Solution Manager 7.2 mainstream maintenance timelines.

Key Transition Principles:

  • Take a phased approach — avoid “big bang” cutovers.
  • Clearly define the scope to avoid scope creep.
  • Apply SAP best practices and tailor phases to business needs.
  • Process Navigator for Transition

 

Typical Customer Path:

  • Move to SAP CALM for Operations
  • Transition to SAP CALM for Implementations
  • Guidance for typical customer situations

 

 

  1. Perform a Readiness Check

 

SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM

 

Before transferring any data, understand what can and cannot be migrated today.

Key Resource:

  • SAP Note 3236443 – SAP Readiness Check for SAP Cloud ALM

Steps:

  1. In Solution Manager, execute program /SDF/RC_ALM_COLLECT_DATA.
  2. Access the SAP Readiness Check cloud application and start a new analysis.
  3. Review the generated usage overview of your current SolMan capabilities.
  4. Identify:
    • What can be migrated directly.
    • What requires manual adjustments.
    • What is currently out of scope (e.g., most operations data).
  1. Prepare Your Data for Transition

Scope Definition

Focus on Solution Documentation (Soldoc) elements currently supported in the transition:

  • Process hierarchy
  • Libraries
  • Business processes
  • Diagrams
  • Documents
  • Test steps

Note: Operations data is generally not in the current migration scope.

     4.Develop a Migration Roadmap

SAP Activate Roadmap "Transition to SAP Cloud ALM"

 

  1. Follow the SAP Activate Methodology
    Use the SAP Activate Roadmap “Transition to SAP Cloud ALM” in the SAP Roadmap Viewer for:
  • Detailed project phases
  • Milestones
  • Task dependencies
  1. Build a Transition Team
  • Include cross-functional members (Basis, functional leads, project managers, change management).
  • Consider SAP consulting or Expert Guided Implementation (EGI) services.
  • Roles: Security Guide for Selective Data Transfer SAP Solution Manager 7.2 to SAP Cloud ALM

 

5.Selective Data Transfer (SDT) Process and Set Up SAP Cloud ALM 

SDT 

 

  1. Scope: Select relevant Solution Manager data for migration.
  2. Export: Download scoped data.
  3. Adjust (optional): Make modifications to fit CALM requirements. (create tags, Users, system groups in SAP CALM)
  4. Import: Upload data into SAP Cloud ALM.
  5. Validate: Verify completeness and correctness in CALM.

Conclusion

Transitioning from SAP Solution Manager 7.2 to SAP Cloud ALM is not a one-time event—it’s a strategic program. By using a structured, phased approach backed by SAP’s tools and best practices, you can minimize disruption, maintain data integrity, and quickly realize the benefits of SAP’s modern, cloud-based ALM platform.

Transition to SAP Cloud ALM

End to End Guide for Transition

entry.title: Re: ABAP Extensibility Guide – Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud - August 2025 Update
entry.content:
Hi @danwal ,

you need to add 4 additional checks: also the "SYCM_ALLOWED_ENH_TECHNOLOGY" check must be added.  This is our standard recommendation for ATC check variant considering the clean core level concept. The predefined ATC check variant ABAP_CLEAN_CORE_DEVELOPMENT will contain exactly these checks: the checks of the ABAP_CLOUD_DEVELOPMENT_DEFAULT plus the 4 listed clean core checks. You don't need to wait for it.

Kind Regards,
Olga.

entry.title: Re: Managing Subscriptions in S/4HANA Public Cloud as a s...
entry.content:
Hello @vasco_keizer 

For a subscription software reseller in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the most fit-to-standard and user-friendly option is:

Service Contracts plus Periodic Billing plus Event-Based Revenue Recognition

  • Create one service contract per customer with multiple items (one per product/license).
  • Assign individual terms, billing plans (annual/quarterly/monthly), and prices per item.
  • Use periodic billing to automate invoice creation and event-based revenue recognition to spread revenue daily over the term.
  • Record purchase costs against the same contract to calculate margins.

Why not Subscription Billing?
Better suited for usage-based or complex recurring pricing; for fixed-price resale, service contracts are simpler and fully standard.

Check below SAP Documentations for your references

 SAP Help – Service Contract Management in Public Cloud

Event-Based Revenue Recognition - Projects

Event-Based Revenue Recognition - Sales Orders

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Restricting Onboarding Dashboard Visibility for Previ...
entry.content:
Onboarding Dashboard Visibility Restrictions

Unfortunately, there is no direct way to completely restrict the previous/current manager's view of the employee in the onboarding dashboard during an internal hire process. The visibility permissions for the onboarding dashboard are primarily controlled through role-based permissions that determine whether users can see new hires and their associated tasks [1].

The onboarding dashboard permissions are configured to allow managers to view employees based on their job relationships and assigned roles. During an internal hire, both the current manager and future manager have legitimate business relationships with the employee, which is why both appear to have visibility [2].

Available Options:

  1. Permission Review: You can review the role-based permissions for the current manager to ensure they only have the minimum required permissions. The dashboard visibility is controlled through permissions such as [1]:

    • Employee Data permissions (First Name, Last Name, Status, Location)
    • Job Information permissions
    • Onboarding Object Permissions (ONB2Process, ONB2AggregatedDetails)

  2. Task Assignment Control: While you cannot remove dashboard visibility entirely, you can ensure that task editing capabilities remain restricted to the future manager only, which appears to be working correctly in your case [2].

The system is designed this way to maintain transparency and ensure that current managers are aware of their direct reports' transitions, even if they cannot take actions on the onboarding tasks. This visibility helps with handover processes and maintaining continuity during the internal hire transition.

If this visibility is causing significant business concerns, you may want to consider discussing alternative workflow approaches with your SAP SuccessFactors consultant or support team.

[1]=https://help.sap.com/doc/205384486bba47da966eb199756bd79b/2505/en-US/Onboarding_2.0.pdf

[2]=https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_SUCCESSFACTORS_ONBOARDING/c94ed5fcb5fe4e0281f396556743812c/4bfed60eb30e46fe8e4e9d95383cad2d.html?locale=en-US&state=PRODUCTION&version=2505

entry.title: Re: IAS/IPS sync job's error log does not display user ID...
entry.content:
IAS/IPS Sync Job Error Log User ID Display

To display user IDs/Employee IDs in the IAS/IPS sync job error logs when downloaded, you need to configure the sf.user.attributes property in your IPS source system configuration.

Solution:

Check and ensure the sf.user.attributes property in your IPS SAP SuccessFactors source system includes the necessary user identification fields. The property should include userId and other relevant attributes [1]. 

The correct configuration should look like:

 

 
sf.user.attributes = userId,username,status,email,lastName,firstName,lastModifiedDateTime,personKeyNav
 

Key Points:

  1. Include userId in attributes: Ensure userId is explicitly listed in the sf.user.attributes property to make it available in the error logs [1]. 

  2. API permissions: Verify that your API user has permission to read the userId property from SAP SuccessFactors [2]. 

  3. Download complete error logs: To get comprehensive error information including user IDs for all failed entities:

    • From the main menu, choose Job Logs tile
    • Select a job that has finished with error
    • Above the Failed Entities table, choose Download All Error Logs for This Job
    • Choose Download to get a ZIP archive with all error logs [3]

    • Transformation consistency: Ensure your source and target system transformations are aligned. If the transformation expects userId but it's not available in the content, this will cause sync failures [2]. 

      If the issue persists after configuring the sf.user.attributes property correctly, you may need to investigate at the SAP SuccessFactors API level to determine why the user data is missing for specific users [1]. 

[1]=https://me.sap.com/notes/2893327

[2]=https://me.sap.com/notes/2905590

[3]=https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/sap-ips-sync-job-failed-logs/qaq-p/12555401/t5/technology-q-a/sap-ips-sync-job-failed-logs/qaq-p/12555401

entry.title: Are Parallel Line tenants considered a type of pre-production environment?
entry.content:
What is the purpose of having Parallel Line tenants? Are these tenants considered pre-production environments and content can be transported to production system?

entry.title: Re: Integration SAP ERP HCM with SuccessFactors Onboardin...
entry.content:
SAP ERP HCM to SuccessFactors Onboarding Integration

For integrating SAP ERP HCM with SuccessFactors Onboarding using Process Integration (PI) as middleware, you need to understand that there isn't typically a direct transaction in SAP ERP HCM to "send" data to SuccessFactors Onboarding. Instead, the data flow follows a different pattern:

Key Integration Process:

The integration is event-driven and triggered by an "External User Eligible for Hire" IS event that is raised when the Onboarding process is completed and the 'Hire Status' is set to "Ready to Hire" in SuccessFactors Onboarding [1].

Data Flow Direction:

  1. From SuccessFactors Onboarding to SAP ERP HCM: When onboarding is completed, candidate data is transferred from SuccessFactors Onboarding to SAP ERP HCM to create or update employee records using transaction PA40 [1].

  2. Transaction PA40: This transaction is used in SAP ERP HCM to perform personnel actions (hiring, transfers, etc.) based on the data received from SuccessFactors Onboarding [1].

Integration Components Required:

  • SAP Process Integration (PI) as middleware
  • API connections for data exchange
  • Custom solution to listen to IS events from SuccessFactors
  • Side-by-Side replication package for ongoing employee data synchronization [1]

Key Considerations:

  • The integration requires a miniature Employee Central setup even when using SAP ERP HCM as the core HR system [1]
  • You'll need to configure number ranges (internal or external) in SAP ERP HCM to handle employee ID generation [1]
  • A custom mapping table may be required to associate SuccessFactors User IDs with SAP PERNRs [1]

Integration Package Available:

SAP provides a Cloud Platform Integration Package specifically for "SuccessFactors HCM Suite Onboarding with SAP ERP HCM" that includes pre-built processes for data exchange, session management, and confirmation workflows [2].

The integration is primarily configured through IMG customization in SAP ERP HCM rather than executing specific transactions to push data to SuccessFactors.

[1]=https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/integrating-onboarding-with-sap-erp-hcm/ba-p/13498574/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/integrating-onboarding-with-sap-erp-hcm/ba-p/13498574

[2]=https://api.sap.com/package/SuccessFactorsHCMSuiteOnboardingwithSAPERPHCM

entry.title: Re: Are Parallel Line tenants considered a type of pre-pr...
entry.content:
Please review the details for Parallel Line (PL) and also transport mechanism for the PL Test system.

Transport Management (Parallel Line) | SAP Help Portal

If you provision for PL line, you will get the PL Customizing tenant (D120) & PL Test Tenant (T120). You can't transport the configurations you made in the parallel line directly into your production system. To take over any business configuration changes from the parallel line to the main line, you need to do a merge.

Some details for PL: 

  1. The parallel line enhances your configuration environment in the 3-system landscape. It includes an additional SAP Central Business Configuration workspace, a parallel customizing tenant in the development system and a parallel test tenant in the test system of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The parallel line complements the customizing, test, and production tenants of the main line as well as the development tenant of the development line.
  2. In principle, the parallel tenants in each system work in a similar way as the tenants from the main line. However, the purpose of parallel tenants is focused primarily on configuration tasks:
  • In the parallel customizing tenant, you perform your configuration activities based on the reference content from the workspace for the parallel line in SAP Central Business Configuration. After finalizing your configuration tasks, transport them to your parallel test tenant.
  • In the parallel test tenant, you test and validate all the configuration you've done in the parallel customizing tenant.

Further details available in our documentation:

Parallel Line in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition | SAP Help Portal

System Landscape with a Parallel Line | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: Re: Essential transfer parameters are missing in record:...
entry.content:
Hello @Tish4 

Thank you for your question. Let me walk you through it.

Here are possible reasons why you received that error message:

It typically occurs because some mandatory data required for posting the Goods Issue from the reservation is missing or incomplete.

It can also happen if the reservation is inconsistent or lacks required reference details due to the way it was created via the Work Order.

Another common cause is insufficient stock availability for the reserved quantity or incorrect posting against the reservation.

My suggestion is to:

Verify the Reservation and Stock. Ensure that the stock material included in the WO reservation actually has sufficient available stock to fulfill the reservation quantity. Check the reservation record details to confirm all required fields and transfer parameters are correctly populated.

Use Correct Transaction or App for Goods Issue to perform the Goods Issue specifically using the "Post Goods Issue" app or appropriate SAP transaction referencing the reservation number. This ensures that the system correctly picks up all associated reservation data.

Then check Reservation Final Issue and Status and make sure the reservation is not flagged as "Final issue" (unless intended) or deleted. Ensure there are no authorization or movement type restrictions preventing the Goods Issue posting.

You can also consult SAP Standard Goods Issue to Reservation Process. SAP expects Goods Issue against reservations to have complete header and item-level data, movement type, plant, account assignment, etc. which are usually inherited from the reservation. Please note that missing or incorrect values in these fields can lead to the mentioned error.

If the error persists after the above checks, please review if there were any custom enhancements or user-exits affecting reservation or Goods Issue handling. Sometimes creating a new reservation and repeating the Goods Issue process can rule out data inconsistencies. For critical production stock issues, please ensure stock is properly updated and not blocked by other reservations or quality inspections.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

 

Goods Issue With Reference to a Reservation

Finally issue flag on Reservations

entry.title: Re: Equivalent function ‘ENQUEUE_E_DSVAS_TRDIR’ in S4HANA
entry.content:
Hi Clayton,

I would recommend:

  • Check whether E_DSVAS_TRDIR exists in your S/4HANA system (using SE11 or SE80).
  • If absent and you simply wish to prevent parallel runs, consider using ES_PROG.
  • If specific TRDIR-level locking is essential, define and use a custom lock object.

Because E_DSVAS_TRDIR is tied to older components that may be removed in S/4HANA, it often won’t exist in newer systems.
If you just need to stop parallel execution, ES_PROG already provides that without recreating the old lock.
If you still need TRDIR-specific locking, you must create your own lock object in SE11 since SAP no longer ships it.

Kind regards,

Jacob Conley

CONLEYTECH LLC

www.linkedin.com/in/jacobrconley

entry.title: Re: SAP Bussiness One Budgetting
entry.content:
Hello @clement4 

Thank you for your question. Let me walk you through it.

In SAP Business One, budgets are set at the GL account level but if you need separate budgets for multiple names or specific assets within one GL account, my advice is to use Cost Centers or Project Codes.

If you choose to do that, here are steps that will enable you achieve separate budgets:

First is to ensure you enable budget functionality in General Settings.

Then create your desired cost centers or projects for each name or asset group. Then ensure to define a budget scenario.

Finally, make sure to enter budgets per GL account and Cost Center or Project.

This steps will allow a granular budget tracking and reporting for different assets or entities under the same GL account.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

Defining the Budget

entry.title: Re: DMS/Attachment functionality in Custom Application in...
entry.content:
Hi @Aakshya,

Yes, you can integrate DMS attachment functionality into your custom application using the SAP BTP Document Management Service - Integration Option.

This solution relies on CMIS-based REST APIs, allowing you to:

  • Create repositories and folders

  • Upload, retrieve, update, and manage documents

  • Handle metadata and versioning

Official SAP References:

  • API Overview - https://api.sap.com/package/SAPDocumentManagementServiceIntegrationOptionCMISAPI/overview

  • CMIS REST API Endpoints - https://api.sap.com/package/SAPDocumentManagementServiceIntegrationOptionCMISAPI/rest

  • Supported CMIS APIs - https://help.sap.com/docs/document-management-service/sap-document-management-service/supporting-cmis-apis

  • Initial Setup Guide - https://help.sap.com/docs/document-management-service/sap-document-management-service/initial-setup-for-document-management-service-integration-option

High-level steps:

  1. Enable the DMS Integration Option in your BTP subaccount.

  2. Create a service instance and generate a service key for authentication.

  3. Use the CMIS REST APIs from your custom app to upload/retrieve files and manage folders.

  4. Optionally, store document IDs in S/4HANA business objects for linkage and traceability.

This approach is secure, scalable, and fully supported for Public Cloud extensions.

Kind regards,

Jacob Conley

entry.title: Re: Unlimited reversal postings on original journal entry
entry.content:
Hi Yuval,

This is standard system behavior in S/4HANA Group Reporting when using a manual document type configured with the automatic reversal flag. With this setting, the system does not block repeated reversals because these postings are intended to support flexible consolidation adjustments across periods or units. This design choice allows correction cycles during group reporting, even if it’s not typical in operational accounting. For document types without the automatic reversal flag, the system restricts multiple reversals to avoid duplicate or inconsistent postings. If you need to prevent unlimited reversals for auto reversal types, you’d have to implement a custom control (for example via BADI_FINCS_JOURNAL_POST) to check for an existing reversal before allowing another one.

For further reference:

  • SAP KBA 3351536 - Group Reporting: Manual document type with auto reversal option being enabled can be reversed multiple times in Mass Reversal app or Post Group Journal Entries app
  • SAP KBA 3430776 - Group Reporting: Auto-reversal in first period of a new fiscal year context on cross-year auto-reversing behavior
  • SAP Learning Journey - Maintaining Group Reporting Document Types, explains configuration of document types and auto-reversal settings

Kind regards,

Jacob Conley
CONLEYTECH LLC
www.linkedin.com/in/jacobrconley

entry.title: Re: DMEE XML File truncated after S/4HANA 2023 upgrade
entry.content:
Hi Alessandro,

This is a known issue in S/4HANA 2023 with DMEE/DMEEX XML output in certain payment formats (including DE_CGI_XML_CT). After the upgrade, XML files generated via FDTA may be truncated or incomplete when the output size exceeds roughly 9,999 characters or when multi-byte characters are involved. Older runs are unaffected because the output was generated under the previous release logic.

Check SAP Note/KBA 3575473 - This documents the truncation issue and affected versions. Apply the correction instructions or the latest support package for your release. Missing or altered declarations can contribute to corruption.

Workarounds until a fix is applied:

  • Split payment runs into smaller batches to keep file size below the truncation threshold.
  • Implement BAdI DMEE_BADI_01 (method MODIFY_OUTPUT_FILE) to control output length/encoding if urgently needed.

References: SAP KBA 3575473 - “DMEE: XML file is truncated”

Kind regards,

Jacob Conley
CONLEYTECH LLC
www.linkedin.com/in/jacobrconley

entry.title: Re: Best practices for implementing EBS in CAMT.053 forma...
entry.content:
Hi Padmasini,

CAMT.053 is the ISO 20022 XML end-of-day account statement format. Compared to MT940, it carries richer, structured data (unlimited remittance lines, standard/proprietary transaction codes, clearer sender/receiver info), enabling higher reconciliation automation. Many banks support both formats during migration, so parallel runs are recommended.

Identifying external transaction codes in CAMT.053:

  • Found in the <BkTxCd> element of the XML
  • Domain (ISO) codes <BkTxCd><Domn>…
  • Proprietary (bank-specific) codes <BkTxCd><Prtry><Cd>

These values are what you maintain in SAP’s EBS config as External Transaction Codes to link to posting rules.

Mapping MT940 to CAMT.053

Mapping is required to keep your posting logic consistent.

  • Build a matrix: MT940 code (tag 61/86) --> CAMT <BkTxCd> --> External Transaction --> Posting Rule.
  • Maintain this in SPRO (Assign External Transaction Codes to Posting Rules).
  • If codes differ significantly or the bank sends non-standard values, use BAdIs (e.g., FIEB_CHANGE_BS_DATA) to translate.
  • Handle reversal indicators explicitly (for example “ENTRY REVERSED”).

Recommended transition approach

  • Run MT940 and CAMT.053 in parallel during testing.
  • Compare postings to ensure CAMT mappings trigger the correct posting rules.
  • Use search strings and reprocessing rules to automate clearing for common patterns.
  • Resolve unmapped codes to avoid errors like FTE_FIEB012.

SPRO Configuration Steps for CAMT.053 EBS

Prerequisites:

  • Maintain house bank/accounts in Manage Bank Accounts (Fiori).
  • Obtain your bank’s CAMT.053 implementation guide + sample XMLs.

Enable CAMT.053

SPRO → Financial Accounting → Bank Accounting → Business Transactions → Payment Transactions → Electronic Bank Statement.

In “Define Formats,” ensure CAMT.053 is active.

2. Make Global Settings for EBS

Define Posting Keys, Document Types, Account Symbols.

Assign Accounts to Symbols.

Define Posting Rules, create Variants, and assign them to Company Codes.

3. Map External Transactions to Posting Rules

Define Transaction Types (if needed).

Assign <BkTxCd> values from the bank to the correct External Transaction + Posting Rule.

Use BAdIs for non-standard mapping logic.

4. Automate with Search Strings

Set search strings to auto-derive customers/vendors or adjust posting rules based on text fields (remittance info, UETR, etc.).

5. Exception Handling

Use Reprocess Bank Statement Items and Manage Bank Statement Reprocessing Rules for unmatched transactions.

6. Testing & Go-Live

Parallel load MT940 & CAMT.053, validate identical postings, fix gaps.

Confirm all codes are mapped to avoid processing errors.

Useful References:

 

  • SAP Help – Processing Bank Statements (Cloud)

  • SAP Help – Assign External Transaction Codes to Posting Rules

  • SAP KBA 3452537 – External transaction code not specified for CAMT.053

  • ISO 20022 CAMT.053 structure guide

Kind regards,

Jacob Conley
CONLEYTECH LLC
www.linkedin.com/in/jacobrconley

entry.title: What is the minimum capacity units (CU) to activate Object Store in SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)?
entry.content:
Symptom: You are unsure of the number of capacity units (CU) required to activate Object Store in Business Data Cloud (BDC). 

Requirements: N/A.

Resolution: The minimum capacity units required to activate Object Store in BDC is 4150.05 CU (128 GB of SAP HANA memory). You can simulate this number in SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator. 

1) Open SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator

2) Select your Hyperscaler and Data Center

3) Click "Add" and double-click "SAP Datasphere"

4) Increase memory in "Compute" card until we have 128 GB

5) Add 1 block (minimum) in "Object Store Storage" card to activate this feature

6) Customize according to your needs in the simulator to have the final CU that you need for your business case

Image 2

Image 3

entry.title: Data-Driven Hiring: Mastering Rate Guidance in SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
Rate Guidance: Simplifying Complex Rate Structures
 

Rate Guidance in SAP Fieldglass offers a streamlined approach for managing the rates of external workers. Unlike permanent employees with fixed salaries, these workers' pay rates can vary based on factors like role, supplier, location, and regional laws.
 

Key Features of Rate Guidance:
 

  • Large Data Volume Management: Use a lookup table to manage rate structures efficiently, associating appropriate rates based on job code, supplier code, site code, and currency.
  • In-depth Information: Access key data including the number of workers hired monthly, the lowest, highest, and mean rates.
  • Market Data Integration: Incorporate trends and comparisons with average rates from other SAP Fieldglass customers, as well as data from the Council for Community and Economic Research (C2ER) and Brightfield TDX.
     

Benefits of Using Rate Guidance:
 

  • Simplification of Complex Rates: Reduce complexity in managing external worker rate structures, allowing for accurate billing by simplifying configuration and maintenance.
  • Streamlined Rate Configuration: Use a lookup table to efficiently handle multiple rate variables such as job role, supplier, location, and pay rate.
  • Improved Efficiency: Easily update rates with a single upload, minimizing time and effort for configuring and maintaining rates.
  • Cost Avoidance and Savings: Report cost savings when reduced rates are accepted by suppliers, gaining negotiation advantages by comparing rates against market averages.
  • Access to Market Data: Include information from other SAP Fieldglass customers, providing insights and benchmarking opportunities for competitive and compliant rate setting.
  • Enhanced Decision-Making: Visualize historical rate information and compare it to market data to make informed decisions about workforce costs and negotiations.
  • Global Legislative Support: Rate guidance is supported in over 180 countries, helping businesses navigate complex rate and legislative requirements such as payroll tax and workers' compensation.
     

Join Our Webinar to Learn More
 

Do you want to learn more about Rates and Rate Guidance in SAP Fieldglass and their benefits? Join us for the next webinar!
 

  • Event Date: August 26, 2025
  • Event Start: 10:00 AM ET
  • Event Link: (NAMER) Data-Driven Hiring: Mastering Rate Guidance in SAP Fieldglass

We look forward to seeing you there!

entry.title: Re: How to generate Payment advise if payment done by app...
entry.content:
Hello @gautam_SAP 

If you’ve completed all the prerequisite steps, such as activating output types, assigning them to the form template, and enabling them in business configuration, but still cannot see the Output Items tab, it is usually caused by one of these reasons:

App/Role restriction

  • The Output Items tab is visible only in certain apps, such as Display Purchase Order, Display Billing Document, and Display Outbound Delivery.
  • Your business role must include the output control business catalogue:
    • Business Catalogue: SAP_BC_OM_OUTPUT_PC (Output Control – Processing)
    • Without this, the tab won’t appear, even if the configuration is correct.

Document type not enabled for output

  • Check the document type in Manage Output Parameter Determination and confirm that there is an active output type for your document. If no active output is available, the system might hide the tab.

Using the wrong app variant

  • Some Manage apps, for example, (Manage Purchase Orders), don’t display the tab you need to access the Display or Change version for the document.

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Event Deferred revenue in FI-CA with negative quantities
entry.content:
Hello @joao_sousa2 

Thank you for your question.

It is a normal and expected behaviour in SAP FI-CA event based deferred revenue processing. The negative quantities represent the accounting reversal entries that reduce the deferred revenue balance when revenue recognition events are confirmed. The invoicing document shows the positive billed quantity, while the deferred revenue postings show the corresponding negative reversal to move amounts from deferred revenue to recognized revenue.

Therefore, confirming execution with negative billing quantities is required and aligns with SAP's standard deferred revenue logic. You can use SAP test reports for example, TEST_DEFREV_TABLE_ENTRIES, TEST_DEFREV_RAISE_EVENT to verify the correct posting of these events.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

Setting up Allowances for the Posting of Deferred Revenues

entry.title: Re: DMEE XML File truncated after S/4HANA 2023 upgrade
entry.content:
Thanks for the follow-up, Alessandro. I suspect your implementation isn’t firing because DMEE_BADI_01 is only used by classic DMEE. After the S/4HANA 2023 upgrade your format DE_CGI_XML_CT is likely running on DMEEX, which calls different enhancement points so DMEE_BADI_01 won’t trigger.

How to confirm DMEE vs. DMEEX:

DMEE --> your tree --> Header: look at Tree Type. If it shows DMEEX Tree, you’re on DMEEX.

SE16N:

DMEEX_FORMATS with your FORMAT_ID (e.g., DE_CGI_XML_CT) --> entry exists = DMEEX.

DMEEFMT with same ID --> entry only here = classic DMEE.

Format attributes: if it points to a class like CL_FIEB_* it’s DMEEX; if it uses RFFO* programs it’s classic DMEE.

What to use on DMEEX:
Implement FIEB_PAYMENT_MEDIUM_FORMAT (SE18/SE19) and set the Filter Value to your exact FORMAT_ID. Use method CHANGE_OUTPUT_FILE to intercept/adjust the XML before it’s saved.

Two-minute “did it fire” test:

In your FIEB_PAYMENT_MEDIUM_FORMAT implementation, open method IF_FIEB_PAYMENT_MEDIUM_FORMAT~CHANGE_OUTPUT_FILE.

Set an external breakpoint there (for your user).

Run FDTA --> Download for the same format/run. If the debugger stops, you’re good.

Optional visible marker (for a single test):

IF sy-uname = 'YOURUSER'.
c_output_string = c_output_string && `<!-- BADI TEST -->`.
ENDIF.

Re-download and confirm the comment appears at the end of the XML, then remove it.

If it still doesn’t stop:

  • Re-check the Tree Type and that the Filter Value equals the format ID shown in FDTA.
  • Make sure the BAdI implementation is Active.

If your variant uses XSLT or a specialized format handler, the alternative enhancement is FIEB_DME_EXIT but in most DMEEX cases FIEB_PAYMENT_MEDIUM_FORMAT is the one that fires during XML creation.

Once you confirm the right BAdI is in play, we can address the truncation itself (batch size, encoding, or applying the relevant SAP correction). Happy to help review a short trace or your tree header screenshot if you can share it.

entry.title: Future Stock Value for Multiple Materials in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, we need to monitor multiple materials. We’re looking for a standard way to include future receipts and issues (from purchase orders, production orders, deliveries).

What standard apps are available in the public cloud edition to achieve this?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Future Stock Value for Multiple Materials in S/4HANA...
entry.content:
Hi,

Thank you for the details.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, for monitoring multiple materials and getting an overview of their stock situation, you can use the following standard options:

  1. Stock – Multiple Materials app
    - Shows current stock quantities and values for multiple materials at once.
    - You can filter by material, plant, storage location, etc.
    - This app reflects the stock situation as of “today” — future projections will need additional reporting.

  2. 'Monitor Material Coverage – Net Segments' or 'Monitor Material Coverage' apps
    - 'Monitor Material Coverage – Net Segments' or 'Monitor Material Coverage' allow you to check supply/demand for several materials simultaneously, including future receipts (purchase orders, production orders) and issues (sales orders, reservations).
    - While these apps don’t directly calculate future stock values, they provide the quantities by date, which can be linked with valuation data.
    - You can see the overview of rescheduling proposals for a planner
    - For additional details check the blog Manage Supply Shortage and Excess Supply with MRP Material Coverage Apps.

Thanks and regards.

entry.title: Re: Learning SAP
entry.content:
Hello @DawnNUK 

There isn’t a completely free, full-version SAP system you can just install locally, but there are a few low-cost or no-cost options you can use to get hands-on practice:

SAP Learning System Access. SAP Learning Hub – Student/Discovery Edition

Official SAP training environment with access to preconfigured SAP systems for exercises.

Cost: Free

Discovery Edition – free, limited learning content (no live system).

Professional/Student Edition paid €20–30/month and includes Learning System Access hours.

Link: https://learning.sap.com/

 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Trial Public Edition

14-day trial of S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with guided scenarios.

Cost: Free.

No full customising; system resets after trial.

Link: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Trial

 

SAP Developer Edition

Downloadable ABAP-based SAP NetWeaver or older S/4HANA Developer Editions for personal learning.

Cost: Free.

Technical focus (ABAP, configuration); not all business modules. Requires Linux VM setup.

Link: SAP Developers Trials and Downloads

 

OpenSAP Courses

Free, interactive SAP learning platform with exercises, some using real SAP trial systems.

Cost: Free.

Link: https://learning.sap.com/opensap-course-migration


If you want practical/business process experience, start with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud trial and SAP Learning Hub Student Edition. For technical/ABAP skills, use the Developer Edition.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: United States Tax depreciation calculations in SAP
entry.content:
Hello @HitenM 

Yes, S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Asset Accounting supports U.S. tax depreciation methods, including MACRS half-year, mid-quarter, and mid-month, as well as bonus depreciation, Sec. 168,000, through specialised depreciation keys and a dedicated tax depreciation area.

Why do you have a different result?

  • Bonus depreciation $60k showing as $30k: If booked as special depreciation with apportionment, the system distributes it over periods. To recognise it fully in the placed-in-service period, post it in the tax area as Unplanned Depreciation, which posts the entire amount immediately.
  • Ordinary depreciation shows as 0: Likely because the period control in your depreciation key delays the start of ordinary depreciation. Use a MACRS key that matches the asset’s class life and convention to obtain the correct prorated amount by 06/30.

SAP Document references:

  • SAP Help – Depreciation in Asset Accounting
  • SAP Fiori App – Post Unplanned Depreciation
  • SAP Help – Mid-Quarter Convention (US)

Let me know if you want further support

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: AI Copilots and the External Workforce: Reimaging the Future with Conversational Intelligence
entry.content:
In today’s fast-moving business landscape, where speed determines market leadership, the way organizations manage external talent is under intense scrutiny. Procurement and HR leaders are expected to deliver more—faster, smarter, and with greater accountability—but they’re often constrained by outdated, manual workflows that lag the pace of change. 

The rise of hybrid work, the surge in contingent labor, and the growing complexity of services procurement have created a perfect storm of operational friction. As pressure mounts to optimize spend, ensure compliance, and secure the right talent at the right time, the disconnect between executive expectations and system capabilities becomes increasingly clear — tools in place often deliver fragmentation, delays, and administrative burden. It’s no longer enough to simply digitize workflows. Executives are demanding real-time visibility, streamlined execution, and actionable insights.  

The current mandate is shifting from basic automation to intelligent orchestration powered by AI and copilots. Enterprise systems are no longer just expected to process tasks—they must evolve to anticipate user needs, guide decision-making, and unlock capacity at scale. Reflecting this shift, 44% of executives identify AI strategy and integration as a top priority for procurement teams over the next 12–18 months. 

As a leader in external workforce, SAP Fieldglass has taken a disciplined, strategic approach to artificial intelligence—one that prioritizes trust, transparency, and tangible business value. Focusing on deeply and seamlessly embedding it in the systems that power external workforce management. Delivering intelligence that understands the complexity of enterprise operations, respects data integrity, and scales with confidence. SAP Fieldglass’s AI is helping businesses run better by turning data into decisions, and decisions into outcomes. That’s what makes its approach essential for organisations navigating transformation at scale.  

 Joule and the Power of GenAI: Embedded Intelligence for Every Workflow 

The launch of Joule, SAP’s copilot, within SAP Fieldglass marks a transformative moment for organizations seeking to elevate their contingent labor and services procurement strategies. Joule is not just another tool—it’s a strategic enabler that redefines how practitioners interact with data, make decisions, and drive operational excellence. 

Joule introduces a conversational interface that allows users to interact with SAP Fieldglass in a natural, intuitive way. By shifting from manual navigation to intelligent dialogue executives and managers can now receive assistance with everyday tedious tasks – including multiple search and navigation enhancements, as well as assistance in the creation of job postings and SOWs – within contingent and Statement of Work (SOW) workflows, simply by engaging through a conversational interface. 

For users focused on speed and scale, Joule delivers a powerful suite of capabilities that streamline decision-making and execution: 

  • It guides users to best-fit templates and intelligently pre-fills key fields such as start dates. 
  • It retrieves complex reports—like quarterly budget and spend, worker headcount, and job postings—with ease. 
  • It quickly surfaces relevant help information from the SAP Help Portal site and actionable insights that would otherwise take hours to uncover. 

Together, these capabilities dramatically reduce time-to-action, minimize manual errors, accelerate the learning curve, and improve the overall user experience. Joule also enhances visibility and precision in workforce planning, empowering users to make informed decisions around vendor spend, talent allocation, and compliance risks. 

Joule is integrated directly into SAP Fieldglass, so it eliminates the need to toggle between systems or undergo extensive training, allowing teams to focus on outcomes rather than processes. This frictionless experience is particularly appealing to executives who value simplicity and efficiency in enterprise technology. 

Security and scalability are foundational to Joule’s design. Built within SAP’s trusted ecosystem, it adheres to rigorous governance standards, ensuring that innovation does not compromise compliance or unconscious bias. For organizations operating across geographies and industries, this means they can deploy Joule with confidence, knowing it meets the highest standards of data protection and operational integrity. 

SAP Fieldglass AI journey 

SAP Fieldglass has been at the forefront of integrating machine learning and artificial intelligence into its solutions for years. From intelligent resume assessments and skill-based candidate matching to automated job description creation, translation, and even SOW generation, SAP has consistently delivered AI-driven capabilities that enhance talent management and procurement processes. These innovations reflect a broader, ongoing commitment to embedding intelligence across the SAP ecosystem—an evolution that continues with the integration of Joule. 

SAP Fieldglass SOW Document AI is an intelligent document processing solution that streamlines the management of Statement of Work (SOW) documents within the SAP Fieldglass platform. Leveraging artificial intelligence and machine learning, it automates the extraction, classification, and validation of key data from SOW PDFs, such as job roles, deliverables, durations, and financial terms. This reduces manual effort, minimizes errors, and accelerates the onboarding and management of external workforce engagements. By integrating seamlessly with the Fieldglass ecosystem, SOW Document AI enhances compliance, improves data accuracy, and helps organizations make faster, more informed decisions when managing services procurement. 

In conclusion 

Looking ahead, Joule will include deeper analytics and expanded use cases across the SAP Business AI portfolio. This evolution will further empower leaders to harness AI in ways that are strategic, scalable, and deeply aligned with their organizational priorities.  

For executives ready to lead this transformation, Joule offers a unique opportunity to reimagine how work gets done. It’s not just about automation—it’s about unlocking new levels of insight, speed, and strategic control.  

SAP helps bring simplicity and clarity to all types of spending from all across a company. SAP invites customers and partners to take part in the transformation, shaping the future of intelligent workforce management together, so that you can take a step toward a smarter, more agile workforce. 

Interested to learn more or activate Joule in your environment?

entry.title: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Malaysia Digital certificate and XML version Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Team,

For one of our Public cloud customer we are implementing the Public cloud along with SAP DRC MY E invoice solution. As per below SAP post, SAP has Update 08/08/2024: The IRBM has released two document type versions: 1.0 and 1.1. The validation of digital signatures is supported by version 1.1 only. To have your digital signatures validated, you need to enter the version number 1.1. - Please refer to SAP Help Portal. 

Electronic Invoicing in Malaysia - SAP Community

In SAP Public cloud currently there is no scope to change the XML version from 1.0 to 1.1 but if the version change is not possible from 1.1 to 1.0 version then in DRC side we still need to add the key pair and also the client id and secret id without which authentication is not completed.

For successfully transmission of an invoice to the IRBM portal the authentication is needed to be with status completed other wise we get below error from the BTP below error 

Error occurred during the TRANSMIT step, detailed information: javax.script.ScriptException: java.lang.Exception: java.lang.RuntimeException: Authentication failed. Please check the incomplete authentication settings of TIN C*** in Communication Settings app.@ line 93 in Get CM Config.groovy Error occurred during the PUSH step, detailed information: Connection to Business System S4C_DEMO returned HTTP status code: 500.

If we add any dummy certificate then authentication status is completed above issue is solved but if the certificate is dummy then we get error of "invalid client " so that means in this case without the correct preprod and PRD certificate we cannot complete the authentication to communicate it to the IRBM portal.

But in this case certificate is needed for signing the XML file in version 1.1 and if public cloud is only offering version 1.0 currently then the config on the DRC for the key pair should it be mandatory as even though the certificate for the digital cert is procured then also it is not useful as the version in the XML side is 1.0 only.

Please let us know if understanding is correct.

entry.title: Re: Document attachment to Maintenance Notification thru Fiori app
entry.content: Thanks for this solution, helped me a lot. OSS Note 3404516 has more details.
